NewsLines.HeadLine: Eurostocks at two-month lows as Wall St opens down

NewsLine.NewsLineText: MARKETS-EUROPE-STOCKS (UPDATE 4)(CORRECTED):Eurostocks at two-month lows as Wall St opens down

body.p: In LONDON item headlined "Eurostocks at two-month lows as Wall St opens down", please read in first paragraph...on Monday...instead of...on Tuesday. (corrects day).
A corrected repeat follows:
By Paul Richardson

LONDON, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Leading European shares fell to two-month intraday lows on Monday as disappointment about the result of the German election added to the already gloomy tone set by worries about the global economy and corporate profits.
A weaker start on Wall Street compounded the bearish mood.

Beleaguered French telecoms equipment group Alcatel led the rout, losing 10 percent after JDS Uniphase Corp, the world's largest supplier of fibre-optic components and modules, lowered its first-quarter sales guidance.
Insurers were also pummelled, with Germany's Munich Re down 8.2 percent after its price target was cut by Morgan Stanley amid concerns about the falling value of its large equity portfolio.
Germany also provided the biggest gainer -- consumer brands company Beiersdorf leaping 16.3 percent on reports that its larger U.S. rival Procter & Gamble was considering buying a stake in the firm.
Analysts said investors had been disheartened the result of Sunday's elections in Germany, which returned the incumbent government to power with a sharply reduced majority.

With Europe's biggest economy stalled, unemployment stuck at around 10 percent and stock markets mired at their lowest level in over five years, investors had hoped a conservative-liberal coalition would initiate structural reforms.

"Certainly (opposition candidate Edmund) Stoiber would have been better received by the market because of his plans for structural reform. The government has not got much of a majority so we can't expect much on reform going forward," said Gareth Evans, European equity strategist at ING Barings.

By 1340 GMT, the FTSE Eurotop 300 index of pan-European blue chips was down 2.0 percent at 832, as losers beat gainers by six-to-one, while the narrower DJ Euro Stoxx 50 index was off 2.3 percent at 2,255.
The Dow Jones industrial average was down 1.3 percent shortly after Wall Street opened, while the Nasdaq Composite shed 1.2 percent.

"The market is dealing with five or six insecurities at the moment -- political, military, economic, corporate and general negative sentiment," said Lex Werkheim, fund manager at Eureffect Asset Management in Amsterdam.
"It's all too much for the market to go up at the moment. We need some of those insecurities to come out into the open before the market can recover," Werkheim said.
ASML PUMMELLED

Among other losers in the chip sector, Dutch semiconductor equipment maker ASML shed 8.8 percent as several major investment banks cut their recommendations, target prices and earnings and sales forecasts for the firm.

Vivendi Environnement fell 9.3 percent on news a sale of the utilities group is being studied by parent Vivendi Universal, as the crushed media empire prepares to outline its new strategy this week. Oil shares provided one of the few bright spots, buttressed by a rise in oil prices to their highest levels in nearly a year.

Near-dated Brent was up 1.1 percent at $28.75 amid fears of supply disruptions after Iraq's decision to reject any new U.N. resolution, and as Israel continued its siege of Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat's Ramallah headquarters.

BP added 0.8 percent, Shell rose 0.9 percent and TotalFinaElf climbed 1.6 percent. Italian energy giant ENI fell 5.6 percent after a broker downgrade. (Additional reporting by Alison Tudor in London and Mark Thompson in Frankfurt)
